properties.text:
[color=black]Blackberries are most commonly found in swamps. Blueberries and raspberries are common in areas with moderate rainfall and moderate temperatures.
Maloberries only grow where it is cold.
[color=black]Corn. Grows fast, grows tall. You can harvest the ears of corn without harvesting the rest of the plant. The ears will grow back.
[color=black]Collecting Food

[color=black]Welcome to the world. First thing is first: you need to survive. For that, you'll need food and shelter.

Look around. Depending on where you are, you'll find plants on the ground that contain edibles.
[color=black]Barley can be found in grassy areas. It can be used to make bread.
[color=black]Berry bushes can be an abundant food source. They come in 4 types: raspberry, blueberry, maloberry, and blackberry.
[b][color=black]Flaked Flint

[color=black]One of the first tools you'll want to make is this flint hatchet. The ingredients are simple: sticks come from harvesting the leaves of trees. You do not need to chop the tree down to acquire sticks -- in fact, you cannot harvest the tree's logs without a hatchet.

[color=black]You'll need to hit the flint against stone in a particular way to flake the flint for use in making a tool. If done right, you'll hear a satisfying "click" sound. Pause between clicks, then try again if the previous attempt did not produce flaked flint.
[b][color=black]Acquiring Hardware

[color=black]Flint is acquired as expected: digging through gravel. However, you can also gather flint in sand if gravel proves difficult to find. It might also be wise to make a shovel, especially if you want lots of flint.
[color=black]Index (click on text)
By: The Wanderlust Team
[color=black]Ore Processing

[color=black]While there are several methods of processing ore, while we're in the Stone Age, we are very limited. For the most part, you're limited to processing copper, tin, zinc, lead, and silver. The easiest method to process these may be the furnace.
[color=black]The furnace will allow you to smelt most ores into their ingot forms -- a notable exception to this is iron. Sadly, the heat produced by the furnace is not enough for iron.

[color=black]At this point, you'll have materials like copper, tin, and zinc. The next step is to turn these into alloys such as bronze and brass. There are two methods to make these alloys: the smeltery and the crucible.

[color=black]The Smeltery
You'll need grout. There are four different recipes for grout:
[color=black]<insert note here about crafting tables>
[color=black]Most of the more useful tools will require you to knap your flint. Knapping flint is done by holding flint in your hand and hitting the flint against a hard surface, such as stone.

[color=black]Which, you'll notice, the shovel reqires a station to craft it. You'll also note that planks are a bit harder to acquire. The solution? Using that hatchet you made earlier can be used to make a work table.
[color=black]Flaked Flint

[color=black]The Flint Pickaxe
You'll need this to collect stone and ore.

[color=black]The Work Blade
You'll need a work blade to make wooden pins, which are needed to make the saw, but it has several other uses as well.

[color=black]The Flint Saw
You may have noticed that planks are harder to craft. You can get around this with a saw. The flint saw is the inferior option, but we can get past that later.

[color=black]The Stone Gallagher
Once you have a pickaxe, you can make this tool.
[color=black]Then you just process the grout in a furnace to make seared bricks. From there, you can make the rest of the smeltery's components.
[color=black]At a minimum, you'll need a smeltery controller, a tank, a drain, a smeltery faucet, and a casting table or basin.

[color=black]It appears that monsters have gotten a bit intelligent in this world. Zombies will attempt to break light sources, doors, and chests or other containers. Skeletons will manipulate redstone devices such as buttons, levers, comparators, and repeaters. Skeletons will also ignite TNT that is left within reach.

However, you can use their slightly increased intelligence against them.

Zombies will attempt to use blocks such as punji sticks reach light sources. Use this behaviour to create traps!
[color=black]Dealing with Monsters

[color=black]  As quickly as possible, you'll wish to convert your wooden doors to copper or iron, and use a pressure plate, especially the security pressure plate, to protect your entrances.

Chests made of tougher materials, such as iron or steel, will also largely be immune to the zombie's desire to break everything you've worked for.
[color=black]See the next chapter in my popular "Getting Through" series: Getting through the Bronze Age!
[color=black]Ash:
[color=black]Ash can be made by putting torches in enclosed areas. The torch will create a cloud that eventually settles into a pile of ash, which can be then picked up.
[color=black]Terra Clay:
[color=black]Tip: use nature's compass to find a specific biome!
[color=black]Terra clay is found in plains and near rivers.
[color=black]Silty dirt is extremely common in the following biomes: cherry blossom grove, lavender fields, prairie, snowy forest, and tundra.
[color=black]Silty Dirt:
[color=black]Finding Ores

[color=black]Copper Ore

Copper is one of the most common ores you can find. You'll find it in several different types of distribution: layered veins with moderately sized motherlodes and long branches; rare, but massive clouds of copper with hints of the cloud near the surface; and small clusters.

[color=black]A copper "cloud" after having the stone stripped away. Note how sparse the ore is spaced.
There is a lot of ore here!
[color=black]The first ores you'll want to find are copper, zinc, or tin. These are all fairly common ores in the Overworld.
[color=black]A copper cluster; commonly found anywhere.

[color=black]Iron Ore
Iron can be found in several different forms. It is likely the single most common material you can find in the overworld. Iron is found as goethite, limonite, hematite, magnetite, taconite, siderite, bog iron, and banded iron.

Hematite and magnetite are the most rich iron ores. They're mostly found in the deepest reaches of the earth. However, magnetite is found near the surface in beaches and deserts while hematite is found near the surface in cold regions.

Goethite, Limonite, and Taconite are found almost anywhere.
[color=black]It is likely little surprise that bog iron is found mostly in swamps. Banded iron is mostly found in plains-like biomes.

[color=black]Lead and Silver Ore
These two ores are almost never found far apart from one another. These ores tend to favor a region about 22 meters above bedrock, though it can also be found in mountains about 70 meters above sea level.

[color=black]Aluminum Ore
Also called Bauxite, this ore is most common at sea level. It can also be found in mountains about 60 meters above sea level.

[color=black]Nickel Ore
Nickel can be found about 16 meters above bedrock. It can also be found in mountains about 120 meters above sea level.

[color=black]Uranium Ore
This radioactive material is incredibly rare, unless you're in wastelands. It will generally be found 16 meters above bedrock.
As a side note, you'll likely have more luck finding uranium underneath lava pools in the Nether.

[color=black]Titanium Ore
Also called rutile, this ore can be found anywhere, but favors oceans. Outside of an ocean, it can be found about 14 meters below sea level. In oceans, it will likely be close to the bottom of the ocean.
[color=black]Chickens need a nest to lay eggs. They also need to be well fed and hydrated, so toss them some seeds and give them a trough full of water.

[color=black]Animals can also be an excellent source of food; not just the animals themselves and the meat that slaughtering them would produce, but the animals can be encouraged to produce other goods as well.
[color=black]Happy, and well-fed pigs are known to find truffles and share them with their owner. Making mud pits for the pigs to play in helps.
[color=black]Truffles can be used to make some excellent foods, such as omelets, soup, and chocolate truffles.
[color=black]Certain trees have fruit growing from the branches, such as this cherry tree.

[color=black]Tin Ore

Tin is less frequent than copper. In general, you can find it as a moderately sized motherlode with long branches. The motherlodes seem to average around 16 meters below sea level. Tin can also be found in giant clouds of ore.

[color=black]Zinc Ore

Much like tin ore, zinc spawns in motherlodes found about 16 meters below sea level. Zinc also rarely can be found in giant clouds of ore.

[color=black]Additional Note:
Sometimes, zombies can be found carrying copper, tin, and zinc ingots. Exterminating zombies may sometimes reveal these ingots.
[color=black]Using the first drying rack, you can place up to 4 fish on it at a time. Fish have a small chance to rot, but this chance is greatly reduced if you salt the fish first.
[color=black]Fish can also be an excellent source of food. You can fish the old fashioned way, using a fishing pole, or you can use nets or traps.
[color=black]Once caught, fish can be eaten raw, cooked, or dried. We'll cover drying first.
[color=black]You'll also need a seasoning rack to make the salt edible.
[color=black]Various types of salt can be found in many locations.

[color=black]Iron is hard to make early on. So is getting a bucket. Try searching for marble structures (from the mod Astral Sorcery) for iron ingots. This could potentially give you a bit of a head start on making a smeltery or starting a farm away from naturally occuring water.
[color=black]Speaking of farming, you don't really need a bucket to move water around. Try using a wooden bowl.

[color=black]If you happen to be making salt in a cold biome, there are a few things you can do. One, you can change the biome. The easiest way to do this is using the Environmental Accumulators found in Dark Temples throughout the world. If you find an Environmental Accumulator in a warm biome, toss a Biome Essence Bottle in the beam, and it will absorb the biome. Carry the biome essence back home and use it where your evaporation tanks are to convert the biome.

Alternatively, put glass over the evaporation tanks. You'll have to fill them with water somehow, though. Pumping water into the tank does not reset the process.

[color=black]Salt is a bit harder to get in this world than most. You can obtain it by finding it (netjry in the overworld, fire salt in the nether, and void salt in the End), or you can make it using an evaporation tank.

If you use an evaporation tank, you have to fill it with water and leave the tank exposed to the sun. It will dry out over time (faster in hot biomes such as deserts). However, rain will reset the process. Is cold biomes, the rain might be frequent enough that you'll never get any salt.

[color=black]Once the evaporation tank is full of salt, you can remove it using a shovel. However, there is a much easier way: place a salt seasoning rack next to the tank. You can't use raw salt (it is poisonous), so you're going to need a salt seasoning rack to make salt anyway.
